intro: Lucuma paraensis, commonly known as the golden apple of the Andes, is a tropical fruit native to the Peruvian highlands. It belongs to the genus Lucuma within the family Ericaceae, which includes other shrubs and trees. The plant produces large, yellow-orange berries that are rich in nutrients such as vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants. Its leaves are thick and waxy, adapted to the cool, high-altitude climate where it thrives. The fruit is often used in traditional Andean cuisine and has gained popularity as a superfood in modern health-conscious diets.
